questions.text: A 25-year-old man is found dead after attempted suicide in his house with brick red colour post mortem lividity on his body. What could be the possible poison ingested by him?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cyanide 

  • The brick red colour is characteristic of Cyanide poisoning and is used for committing suicide.
  • Brick red colour occurs due to high O2 in venous blood as tissues are not able to use O2.

Other Options: Explained in the educational objective below

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

 

#The terminology Cherry red, Bright red, Brick red, and Bright Pink are used sometimes interchangeably in some books. Choose the best choice accordingly.

 

 

Ref: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Dr. K.S. Narayana Reddy and Dr. O.P. Murty, 33rd edition, Page no. 155

questions.text: During a forensic investigation, a medical examiner is called to a crime scene where a body has been found. The examiner notices a distinctive smell of burnt rope at the scene. This observation is key to determining the type of poisoning that may have occurred. Based on this clue, what is the most likely cause of the poisoning?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cannabis

 

 

Option B:

 

The smell of burnt rope is characteristically associated with cannabis. Cannabis, when burnt, emits a characteristic odor that is often likened to that of burnt rope or grass.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Aluminum phosphide - Fishy smell due to phosphine gas.

 

Option C. Arsenic - Garlic like odor

 

Option D. Cyanide - Can have a bitter almond scent, and only detectable by certain individuals.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Smell due to various poisons.

 

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 624

questions.text: In a rural clinic, a medical officer is faced with a case of acute poisoning. A 25-year-old patient has been brought in after ingesting an unknown substance at home. The medical officer needs to quickly administer an initial treatment to reduce the absorption of the poison. In preparing an emergency response, the medical officer considers the components of the universal antidote. Which of the following substances, commonly available in medical settings, is a part of this universal antidote and should be administered in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Activated charcoal

 

The universal antidote traditionally consists of Activated Charcoal, Tannic Acid, and Magnesium Oxide (referred to as "ATM"). Among these, Activated Charcoal is the most commonly used and effective agent in cases of unknown poisoning. It works by adsorbing a wide variety of toxic substances, preventing their absorption in the gastrointestinal tract, and is used as a first-line treatment in many poisoning scenarios.

 

In cases of acute poisoning, especially when the ingested substance is unknown, activated charcoal is administered as it can help reduce the absorption of many types of poisons.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Copper sulfate: This is not part of the universal antidote and is not used in acute poisoning cases. In fact, copper sulfate is toxic itself and is not recommended for general use as an antidote.

 

Option C. Egg white: Egg white can sometimes be used in poisoning cases involving corrosive agents or heavy metals, but it is not a part of the universal antidote.

 

Option D. Starch: Starch may be used in cases of iodine poisoning but is not a general antidote for unknown poisoning and is not part of the universal antidote.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of acute poisoning, especially when the substance is unknown, activated charcoal is the key component of the universal antidote and is effective in reducing the absorption of many toxic substances.

questions.text: In OPC poisoning, treatment was done with atropine and pralidoxime. Hyperthermia occurs. What could be the cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Atropine Toxicity

 

Atropine is an anticholinergic drug used in the treatment of organophosphate poisoning to counteract the effects of excessive acetylcholine. However, excessive doses of atropine can lead to atropine toxicity, which includes symptoms of anticholinergic syndrome such as hyperthermia (due to reduced sweating), tachycardia, dry skin, flushing, and confusion.

 

In OPC poisoning, the cholinergic effects cause excessive sweating and a decrease in body temperature. When atropine is administered in large doses, the opposite effect occurs: inhibition of sweating leads to hyperthermia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspiration Pneumonia: While this is a potential complication of OPC poisoning, it would not directly cause hyperthermia. It would more likely lead to respiratory symptoms.

 

Option C. Oximes toxicity: Oximes (e.g., pralidoxime) are used to reactivate cholinesterase but are not commonly associated with hyperthermia as a side effect.

 

Option D. Cyanosis: Cyanosis refers to a bluish discoloration due to inadequate oxygenation and is unrelated to hyperthermia. It would not cause an increase in body temperature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atropine toxicity can cause hyperthermia due to its anticholinergic effects, which inhibit sweating and increase body temperature. In the treatment of OPC poisoning, careful monitoring of atropine dosage is essential to avoid these toxic effects.

choices.text: Viral infection affecting erythropoiesis, causing aberrant RNA synthesis
Lead poisoning leading to abnormal iron metabolism, leading to intracellular iron accumulation within red blood cells
Autoimmune hemolytic anemia, caused by the production of autoantibodies against red blood cell antigens
Lead poisoning affecting heme synthesis and resulting in aggregates of ribosomal material within red blood cells

questions.text: A 7-year-old child from an environment presents with pallor, fatigue, and abdominal discomfort. Laboratory investigations reveal a hemoglobin level of 9.5 g/dL and a peripheral blood smear demonstrates a peculiar finding shown below. Which of the following differential diagnoses is most likely responsible for this finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lead poisoning affecting heme synthesis and resulting in aggregates of ribosomal material within red blood cells.

 

The clinical presentation of pallor, fatigue, and abdominal discomfort along with the laboratory findings suggest a diagnosis of lead poisoning. The presence of basophilic stippling in the red blood cells, as observed in the peripheral blood smear, is a hallmark feature of lead poisoning. Basophilic stippling represents aggregates of ribosomal material that remain in red blood cells due to the disruption of heme synthesis caused by lead toxicity.

 

Lead interferes with the activity of several enzymes in the heme synthesis pathway, leading to defective red blood cell maturation and characteristic basophilic stippling.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Viral infection affecting erythropoiesis, causing aberrant RNA synthesis: Incorrect. While viral infections can affect erythropoiesis, they do not typically lead to the basophilic stippling seen in lead poisoning.

 

Option B. Lead poisoning leading to abnormal iron metabolism, causing intracellular iron accumulation within red blood cells: Incorrect. Lead poisoning does not cause intracellular iron accumulation but affects heme synthesis, leading to the formation of ribosomal aggregates within red blood cells, which is reflected as basophilic stippling.

 

Option C. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia, caused by the production of autoantibodies against red blood cell antigens: Incorrect. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia typically causes hemolysis and spherocytes in the blood smear but does not result in basophilic stippling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Students should recognize basophilic stippling as a key feature of lead poisoning, resulting from the disruption of heme synthesis and the accumulation of ribosomal material in red blood cells. This is important in diagnosing children exposed to lead, which can lead to significant anemia and other systemic effects

questions.text: Identify the plant shown in the image below and the condition it is responsible for?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ergot Poisoning

 

The image shows rye plants infected with ergot, a fungal disease caused by Claviceps purpurea. This fungus produces toxic alkaloids known as ergot alkaloids, which can lead to ergotism or ergot poisoning when ingested.

 

Ergot poisoning typically manifests with two types of symptoms:

 

  1. Convulsive ergotism: characterized by seizures, muscle spasms, and hallucinations.
  2. Gangrenous ergotism: due to vasoconstriction, leading to poor circulation, and gangrene in the extremities.

 

Historically, ergotism has been associated with contaminated rye bread.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Opioid Poisoning: Incorrect. Opioid poisoning is caused by substances like morphine or heroin and typically presents with CNS depression, miosis, and respiratory depression, not related to ergot-infected rye.

 

Option B. Cannabis Poisoning: Incorrect. Cannabis poisoning involves symptoms like delirium, euphoria, and hallucinations but is not associated with ergot-infected plants.

 

Option D. Dhatura Poisoning: Incorrect. Dhatura poisoning involves anticholinergic symptoms like delirium, dry mouth, mydriasis, and hallucinations, which are unrelated to ergot poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Students should recognize that ergot poisoning arises from consuming rye or other grains infected by the fungus Claviceps purpurea, and it can result in severe vasoconstrictive and neurologic symptoms.

questions.text: In a case of heavy metal poisoning, the emergency department team is considering the use of British Anti-Lewisite (BAL) as a chelating agent. Understanding the specific indications for BAL is crucial for effective treatment. For which of the following heavy metal poisonings is BAL not indicated?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cadmium

 

Option C:

 

BAL (British Anti-Lewisite) is not effective in treating cadmium poisoning. BAL is primarily used for chelation therapy in lead, mercury, and arsenic poisonings. The complex of the agent and metal is more water-soluble than the metal itself, resulting in higher renal excretion of the complex. They can form stable, soluble complexes with calcium and certain heavy metals.

 

Chelating Agents - are used as specific antidotes against some heavy metal poisoning, as they have greater affinity for the metals as compared to the endogenous enzymes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lead: BAL is effective.

 

Option B. Mercury: BAL is used as a chelator.

 

Option D. Arsenic: BAL is indicated for arsenic poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BAL (British anti-lewisite, dimercaprol):

 

  • It is used in arsenic, lead, bismuth, copper, mercury, gold and other heavy metal poisoning.
  • Many heavy metals have affinity for sulfhydryl (–SH) radicals, combine with them in tissues and deprive the body of the use of respiratory enzymes. BAL has two unsaturated –SH groups which combine with the metal and thus prevent the union of the metal with the –SH group of the respiratory enzyme system.
  • Dose: 10% solution in oil, 3–5 mg/kg IM 4 hourly for 2 days, 6 hourly on 3rd day and then 12 hourly for next 10 days.
  • Side effects: Nausea, vomiting, headache and hypertension.
  • Contraindicated in liver damage, G-6-PD deficient individuals, and cadmium and iron poisoning (since dimercaprol-cadmium and dimercaprol-iron complex is itself toxic).

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 518

questions.text: Match the following drugs with the correct antidote from the list provided:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-ii, 2-i, 3-iv, 4-iii


Explanation

 

1. Opioid - ii. Naloxone. Naloxone is a known opioid antagonist that reverses the effects of opioid overdose, making it the correct antidote for opioids.

 

2. Dhatura - i. Physostigmine. Dhatura contains anticholinergic alkaloids, and Physostigmine, a cholinesterase inhibitor, is used to counteract the anticholinergic effects of Dhatura poisoning.

 

3. Methotrexate - iv. Leucovorin. Leucovorin (Folinic acid) is used as an antidote for Methotrexate toxicity, as it helps to reduce the drug's side effects and counteract its action.

 

4. Benzodiazepine - iii. Flumazenil. Flumazenil is a benzodiazepine receptor antagonist and is used as an antidote for benzodiazepine overdose.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents to ED in a coma with CPR in progress. A friend found him in the schoolyard. His friend confesses that the patient has been depressed over the past several days. His initial labs reveal hypocalcemia and a severe metabolic acidosis. The urine shows calcium oxalate crystals. What was the toxic ingestion?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ethylene Glycol

 

The presence of calcium oxalate crystals in the urine, along with hypocalcemia and severe metabolic acidosis, is highly indicative of ethylene glycol poisoning. Ethylene glycol, found in antifreeze, is metabolized into toxic compounds, including glycolic acid and oxalic acid. Oxalic acid binds with calcium to form calcium oxalate crystals, which can cause kidney damage and hypocalcemia. The metabolic acidosis results from the accumulation of toxic metabolites. Ethylene glycol poisoning can be life-threatening and requires immediate treatment with fomepizole or ethanol, which block the metabolism of ethylene glycol.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methanol: Methanol poisoning causes metabolic acidosis but is associated with visual disturbances and does not produce calcium oxalate crystals in the urine.

 

Option C. Organophosphates: Organophosphate poisoning presents with symptoms of cholinergic excess (salivation, lacrimation, diarrhea, etc.), but it does not cause hypocalcemia or calcium oxalate crystals.

 

Option D. Ethanol: Ethanol can cause metabolic acidosis, but it does not lead to hypocalcemia or the formation of calcium oxalate crystals in the urine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethylene glycol poisoning is characterized by severe metabolic acidosis, hypocalcemia, and calcium oxalate crystals in the urine due to the toxic metabolites of ethylene glycol.

questions.text:
An approximately twenty-something year old female presents to the emergency department after she collapsed outside a bar.

 

Physical Examination: T: 97.5Â°F HR: 60 bpm RR: 5 breaths per minute BP: 75/57 mm Hg 

 

Pupils are miotic but equal. 

 

Pulmonary: Clear to auscultation. 

 

CV: Regular rate and rhythm.

 

 Abdomen: Normal 

 

Neurologic: GCS = 6 (E1V1M4).

 

Best treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Naloxone

 

The patient's clinical presentation, including severely depressed respiratory rate (RR 5), miosis (pinpoint pupils), and low blood pressure, is highly indicative of opioid overdose. Opioid toxicity causes central nervous system depression, respiratory depression, and miosis. The treatment of choice in opioid poisoning is Naloxone, an opioid antagonist that rapidly reverses the effects of opioids by competitively binding to opioid receptors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Flumazenil: Flumazenil is a benzodiazepine antagonist used to reverse benzodiazepine overdose, but it is not effective in opioid poisoning.

 

Option C. Naltrexone: Naltrexone is also an opioid antagonist but is primarily used in long-term treatment for opioid dependence. It is not suitable for acute overdose management, where naloxone is the preferred antidote.

 

Option D. N-Acetyl Cysteine: N-Acetyl Cysteine is used as an antidote for acetaminophen (paracetamol) overdose and is not relevant in the treatment of opioid toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of opioid overdose, characterized by severe respiratory depression and miosis, Naloxone is the antidote of choice for rapid reversal of the opioid effects.

questions.text: Alopecia, madarosis & skin rash, painful peripheral neuropathy, and confusion with lethargy are seen in?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Thallium poisoning

 

Thallium poisoning is known for presenting with alopecia (hair loss), madarosis (loss of eyelashes or eyebrows), and a characteristic painful peripheral neuropathy. Thallium is highly toxic, and its symptoms often include neurological manifestations such as painful peripheral neuropathy, confusion, and lethargy. Additionally, skin changes such as a rash can occur, and alopecia is a hallmark sign of thallium poisoning.

 

Peripheral neuropathy caused by thallium is notably painful and often involves both sensory and motor components. Other symptoms may include gastrointestinal distress and psychiatric disturbances such as confusion and lethargy. The presence of alopecia is a significant clue that strongly points toward thallium toxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Copper poisoning: Copper toxicity primarily affects the gastrointestinal tract and liver, leading to symptoms such as vomiting, jaundice, and abdominal pain. It is not typically associated with alopecia, painful neuropathy, or madarosis.

 

Option B. Arsenic poisoning: Arsenic poisoning can cause peripheral neuropathy, but it is generally sensory before motor, and while it can cause skin changes, it does not typically cause alopecia or madarosis. Arsenic poisoning is more associated with gastrointestinal symptoms and skin hyperpigmentation.

 

Option C. Selenium poisoning: Selenium toxicity can lead to hair and nail loss, but it does not cause the painful peripheral neuropathy seen in thallium poisoning. Selenium toxicity is also rare and presents with different systemic symptoms such as a garlic odor on the breath.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thallium poisoning is characterized by alopecia, madarosis, painful peripheral neuropathy, and neurological symptoms such as confusion and lethargy. The presence of hair loss is a distinctive feature that points towards thallium toxicity in cases of suspected poisoning.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male is brought to the emergency department with agitation, dilated pupils, and tachycardia. He appears restless and paranoid, and he is sweating profusely. His blood pressure is elevated. What is the likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute Cocaine poisoning

 

The patientâs symptoms, including agitation, dilated pupils, tachycardia, paranoia, sweating, and elevated blood pressure, are classic signs of acute cocaine poisoning. Cocaine is a potent stimulant that increases sympathetic nervous system activity, leading to increased heart rate (tachycardia), dilated pupils (mydriasis), and hypertension. The patientâs restlessness, agitation, and paranoia are also consistent with the CNS stimulant effects of cocaine.

 

In contrast, opioid and benzodiazepine overdoses are typically characterized by CNS depression, not agitation, while alcohol intoxication usually results in slurred speech, impaired motor function, and CNS depression rather than the hyperactive state seen here.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute Opioid overdose: Incorrect. Acute opioid overdose typically presents with CNS and respiratory depression, miosis (constricted pupils), and bradycardia, none of which are present in this case.

 

Option B. Acute Benzodiazepine overdose: Incorrect. Benzodiazepines also cause CNS depression and sedation, not agitation and hyperactivity. They typically do not cause the dilated pupils and tachycardia seen here.

 

Option D. Acute Alcohol intoxication: Incorrect. Acute alcohol intoxication generally causes CNS depression, impaired coordination, and slurred speech. It does not cause the intense agitation, tachycardia, or dilated pupils seen in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Students should recognize the hallmark signs of acute cocaine poisoning, which include agitation, dilated pupils, tachycardia, and elevated blood pressure, due to its powerful stimulant effects on the central nervous system and cardiovascular system.

choices.text: Applying a tourniquet above the bite site to restrict blood flow and prevent venom spread.
Cutting open the wound and attempting to suck out the venom.
Immobilizing the affected limb at or slightly below heart level and transporting the person to a medical facility.
Applying ice packs directly to the bite area to reduce swelling and pain.

questions.text: A hiker in a forested area is bitten by a snake while exploring. Hiker begins to experience symptoms such as swelling, pain, and bruising at the bite site. The hiker remains conscious but is anxious. What is the most appropriate initial first aid response for this snake bite?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Immobilizing the affected limb at or slightly below heart level and transporting the person to a medical facility.

 

Option C:

 

The appropriate first aid response for a snake bite involves immobilizing the affected limb (if the bite is on an extremity) and keeping it at or slightly below heart level. This helps slow the spread of venom through the lymphatic system. Use a splint or any available materials to immobilize limb.

 

First Aid treatment outside the hospital setting has very limited role in snake bite management.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Applying a tourniquet above the bite site to restrict blood flow and prevent venom spread. It can lead to gangrene.

 

Option B. Cutting open the wound and attempting to suck out the venom. It can introduce infections, increase absorption of the venom and increase local bleeding.

 

Option D. Applying ice packs directly to the bite area to reduce swelling and pain. While ice packs are recommended in scorpion bite, it is not to be given in snake bite. Snake venom can contain enzymes that cause tissue damage and affect blood circulation. Cold temperature can constrict blood vessels and worsen the local damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 564

choices.text: Apply a tourniquet proximal to the sting site
Cleanse the wound and apply ice packs

questions.text: A 30-year-old individual presents to the emergency department with severe pain, restlessness, hypertension, tachycardia, and sweating after being stung by a scorpion. The sting site is red and swollen, with no signs of necrosis. What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Administer prazosin

 

Option C:

 

Patient is bitten by a scorpion bite and is having symptoms of autonomic storm (restlessness, hypertension, tachycardia, sweating), which is treated by Prazosin.

 

 Clinical Manifestations of Scorpion bite:

 

Main manifestation of scorpion bite is adrenergic (autonomic storm). Sometimes Cholinergic (muscarinic) storms occur.

 

  • Adrenergic Storm: Tachycardia, peripheral vasoconstriction, hypertension, diaphoresis, hyperthermia, tachypnea, mydriasis, tremor, convulsions.
  • Cholinergic syndrome: Salivation, sweating, urinary incontinence, diarrhea), miosis, bronchospasm, bradycardia with hypotension and, priapism in males.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Administer antivenom immediately: Antivenom is given only in cases of severe envenomation with significant systemic symptoms, such as respiratory distress, cardiovascular instability etc.

 

Option B. Apply a tourniquet proximal to the sting site: Applying a tourniquet can worsen tissue damage, delay proper wound care, and increase the risk of complications.

 

Option D. Cleanse the wound and apply ice packs: For cases with mild local symptoms, wound cleansing to prevent infection and the application of ice packs or cold compresses to the sting site can help alleviate pain and reduce swelling. However, in cases of significant systemic symptoms like restlessness, hypertension, and tachycardia, addressing the autonomic effects with prazosin is more crucial. The wound care is secondary, and ice pack can be applied later on.

 

Note - While ice packs are recommended in scorpion bite, it is not to be given in snake bite. Snake venom can contain enzymes that cause tissue damage and affect blood circulation. Cold temperature can constrict blood vessels and worsen the local damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management of Scorpion bite:

 

  • Cold compress or Ice pack
  • Prazosin therapy–a post-synaptic alpha1, adreno-receptor antagonist–is the first line of management. It suppresses sympathetic outflow.
  • Scorpion Antivenom: Anti-venom has to be given within 30 minutes of sting to be effective. So useful only in limited cases which present very early. Also, it is reserved for cases of severe envenomation only.

 

Ref: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3/e. Pg 534

questions.text: A middle-aged man from West Bengal presents to the clinic with complaints of numbness and tingling in his hands and feet, thickened patches of skin, distinctive lines across his nails, and "raindrop" pigmentation on his hands. These symptoms have progressively worsened over several months. Given the patient's geographic location and the constellation of symptoms, you suspect chronic exposure to a toxic substance. Which of the following toxins is most likely responsible for the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arsenic

 

Option B:

 

The symptoms mentioned in the question are classic features of chronic arsenic poisoning.

 

Chronic Arsenic poisoning: It is insidious in nature. The onset of symptoms usually occurs after 2–8 weeks of exposure.  Chronic poisoning may occur among persons engaged in smelting and refining of ores and in the subliming of arsenic in the manufacture of weed killers, dyes etc.

 

Clinical Features:

 

  1. GIT symptoms: loss of weight, malaise, loss of appetite, salivation, colicky pain, diarrhoea and vomiting.
  2. Liver: Hepatomegaly, jaundice, cirrhosis
  3. Skin symptoms: usually begin with a persistent erythematous flush leading to hyperkeratotic skin and desquamation. Hyperkeratosis is most prominent in the distal parts of the body. Pigmentation is patchy (‘raindrops pigmentation). Skin cancer (Squamous cell carcinoma and basal cell carcinoma) also occurs.
  4. Nails: Aldrich Mees lines (transverse white striae of the fingernails) may also be seen.
  5. Hairs: Alopecia occurs
  6. Hematological: Anemia, leukopenia, Thrombocytopenia and Bone marrow hypoplasia are seen.  Anemia is normocytic and normochromic.
  7. Peripheral neuropathy:  Sensory and motor polyneuritis (sensory  symptoms  usually  predominate)  manifesting  as numbness and tingling in a ‘stocking glove’ distribution.
  8. Blackfoot disease: Due to platelet activation and hypercoagulability of blood in peripheral arteries.
  9. Encephalopathy
  10. Nephritis

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lead exposure typically presents with gastrointestinal distress, anemia, and neurological symptoms such as peripheral neuropathy, but it does not commonly cause hyperkeratosis or "raindrop" pigmentation.

 

Option C. Thallium poisoning is known for causing severe alopecia (hair loss) and painful neuropathies, but it does not typically present with raindrop pigmentation or Mees' lines.

 

Option D. Mercury exposure can lead to neurological symptoms and acrodynia (pink disease), but it is not associated with the specific dermatological findings seen in arsenic poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The dermatological manifestations of chronic arsenic poisoning - Rash resembling fading measles rash, Speckled brown pigmentation, mostly on the skin flexures, temples, shoulders, eyelids and neck (raindrop pigmentation). Macular areas of depigmentation may appear on normal/hyperpigmented skin (leucomelanosis). Hyperkeratosis of the palms and soles with irregular thickening of the nails and development of white bands of opacity in the nails of fingers and toes (called Aldrich-Mees lines). Brittle nails and alopecia are also seen.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 540

questions.text: Treatment of methyl alcohol poisoning includes all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Forced Alkaline Diuresis

 

Forced Alkaline Diuresis (Option D) is not part of the treatment for methyl alcohol poisoning because it is not effective for excreting strong acids like formic acid. Forced alkaline diuresis is primarily used to enhance the elimination of weak acids, such as barbiturates, chlorpropamide, methotrexate, and salicylates.

 

The treatment of methyl alcohol (methanol) poisoning focuses on preventing the formation of toxic metabolites (formic acid) and removing them from the body. Methyl alcohol is metabolized by the enzyme alcohol dehydrogenase, which converts it to formaldehyde and subsequently to formic acid, leading to metabolic acidosis and toxic effects. 

 

Other Options:

 

The main treatments are:

 

Option A. Ethanol and Option B. Fomepizole: Both ethanol and fomepizole inhibit alcohol dehydrogenase, preventing methanol from being converted into toxic metabolites.

 

Option C. Hemodialysis: Used to remove methanol and formic acid from the bloodstream, helping to reduce acidosis and systemic toxicity.

 

Note: 

 

Sodium Bicarbonate â Administered to correct metabolic acidosis caused by the accumulation of formic acid.

 

Educational Objective:


Forced alkaline diuresis is ineffective in treating methyl alcohol poisoning because it cannot eliminate strong acids like formic acid. The primary treatments include ethanol or fomepizole, hemodialysis, and sodium bicarbonate for acidosis management.

questions.text: A middle aged man from West Bengal presents with paraesthesia of hands and feet, hyperkeratosis, lines in the nails and rain drop pigmentation in the hands. The most likely causative toxin for the above mentioned symptoms is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arsenic

 

The symptoms mentioned in the question are classic features of chronic arsenic poisoning.

 

Chronic Arsenic poisoning: It is insidious in nature. The onset of symptoms usually  occurs  after 2â8  weeks of exposure.  Chronic  poisoning  may  occur among persons engaged in smelting and refining of ores and in the subliming of arsenic in the manufacture of weed killers, dyes etc.

 

Clinical Features of Chronic Arsenic poisoning:

 

  1. GIT symptoms: loss of weight, malaise, loss of appetite, salivation, colicky pain, diarrhoea and vomiting.
  2. Liver: Hepatomegaly, jaundice, cirrhosis
  3. Skin symptoms: usually begin with a persistent erythematous flush leading to hyperkeratotic skin and desquamation. Hyperkeratosis is most prominent in the distal parts of the body. Pigmentation is patchy (âraindrops pigmentation). Skin cancer (Squamous cell carcinoma and basal cell carcinoma) also occurs.
  4. Nails: Aldrich Mees lines (transverse  white  striae  of  the fingernails) may also be seen.
  5. Hairs: Alopecia occurs
  6. Hematological: Anemia, leukopenia, Thrombocytopenia and Bone marrow hypoplasia are  seen.  Anemia is normocytic and normochromic
  7.  Peripheral neuropathy: Sensory  and  motor  polyneuritis (sensory  symptoms  usually  predominate)  manifesting  as numbness and tingling in a âstocking gloveâ distribution.
  8. Blackfoot disease: Due to platelet activation and hypercoagulability of blood in peripheral arteries.
  9. Encephalopathy
  10. Nephritis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lead: Symptoms Abdominal pain, anemia, neurological deficits, but not specifically hyperkeratosis, Mees lines, or raindrop pigmentation.

 

Option C. Thallium: Symptoms Gastrointestinal disturbances, alopecia, peripheral neuropathy, but lacks the specific skin changes and nail lines associated with arsenic.

 

Option D. Mercury: Symptoms: Tremors, memory loss, gingivitis, and neurological symptoms, but does not cause hyperkeratosis or Mees lines.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic arsenic poisoning presents with distinctive symptoms such as paraesthesia, hyperkeratosis, Aldrich Mees lines, and raindrop pigmentation, making it the most likely cause of the described symptoms.

questions.text: Hatter shake is seen in which poisoning?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mercury

 

"Hatter shake," also known as "Danbury tremor" or "glass blowerâs shake," is a classic symptom of mercury poisoning. This type of tremor is typically coarse and begins in the hands, later spreading to other parts of the body. The name âHatter shakeâ originates from historical cases in hat-makers who were frequently exposed to mercury compounds during the hat-making process. As the tremors become more severe and widespread, they may progress to a condition called âshaking palsyâ or concusio mercuralis, where physical tasks become almost impossible due to the intense shaking. This symptom is a distinctive sign of mercuryâs effect on the nervous system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lead: Lead poisoning affects multiple systems, particularly causing neurotoxicity, abdominal pain, and anemia. However, it does not commonly lead to the coarse tremors seen in mercury poisoning.

 

Option C. Arsenic: Arsenic poisoning presents with symptoms such as skin changes, peripheral neuropathy, and gastrointestinal distress but does not cause the specific tremor associated with mercury.

 

Option D. Thallium: Thallium poisoning often results in neurological symptoms, including pain, paresthesias, and hair loss (alopecia), but it does not cause the classic coarse tremor known as the "Hatter shake."

 

Educational Objective:

 

"Hatter shake" is a classic tremor associated with mercury poisoning, beginning in the hands and potentially spreading throughout the body, where it can progress to shaking palsy.

questions.text: Opium, a substance commonly associated with opioid overdose, is derived from which part of the plant?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Unripe capsule

 

Option D:

 

  1. Opium is a grey mass with bitter taste, obtained on drying the milky latex  of  unripe  capsule  of  poppy  plant,  Papaver somniferum.
  2. Incising the capsule exudes  the  latex which  has  the  crude  opium in  it
  3. After the opium is removed, it can be refined into heroin, morphine, and codeine.
  4. Seeds inside the capsule are nonpoisonous and called khaskhas which constitute a condiment in Indian cooking.

 

The below image shows Unripe poppy capsule with incisions

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The leaf of the poppy plant does not contain significant amounts of opiate substances.

 

Option B. The root of the poppy plant is not the source of opium.

 

Option C. While poppy seeds can contain trace amounts of opiates due to contamination from other parts of the poppy plant, they are not a direct source of opium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Opium - Toxic part: Unripe fruit capsule, latex juice.

 

  • Latex is obtained by lacerating (‘scoring’) the immature seed pods; the latex leaks out and dries to a sticky brown residue. This is scraped off the fruit.
  • Seeds are non-poisonous and are called ‘khaskhas’ which constitutes a condiment in cooking.
  • Active Principles - The latex juice of opium has about 25 alkaloids, divided into two groups: Phenanthrene derivatives (main narcotic constituents) and Benzyl-isoquinolone derivatives (no significant CNS effects).

 

Note - Opium disappears with putrefaction, so it may not be detected in putrefied bodies.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 584

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department with agitation, mydriasis, and profuse sweating. He reports a history of substance abuse and mentions recent use of a white powdery substance at a party. On examination, his vital signs are elevated, and he is experiencing palpitations. What is the most likely substance responsible for his current clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cocaine

 

Option C:

 

Cocaine is a potent stimulant that leads to increased sympathetic activity. Clinical features of acute cocaine intoxication include agitation, mydriasis, elevated vital signs (tachycardia), and profuse sweating.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. MDMA (Ecstasy): MDMA (Methylene-dioxy-methamphetamine or ecstasy or Molly) is similar to mescaline and also known as one of the 'club drugs' or ‘rave drug’. It is a stimulant with hallucinogenic properties, supposed to interact with serotoninergic neurons in the CNS (typical effects include increased empathy and sensory perception). It is less likely to cause marked agitation and mydriasis compared to cocaine.

 

Option B. Marijuana: Marijuana use is associated with relaxation, euphoria, and altered perception. It is unlikely to cause the marked agitation and sympathetic overactivity seen in the patient.

 

Option D. Heroin: Heroin is an opioid and typically causes sedation, respiratory depression, and constricted pupils (miosis). It does not typically produce the sympathetic overactivity seen with cocaine use.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The characteristic clinical features of acute cocaine intoxication, includes agitation, mydriasis, elevated vital signs, and profuse sweating.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 584

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient is brought to the emergency department of a district hospital by his coworkers after collapsing in an industrial area known for chemical manufacturing. Upon regaining consciousness, the medical officer notes that the patient exhibits no apparent physical injuries, but there is a distinct "rotten egg" odor on his breath. The patient's vital signs are stable. Considering the industrial setting and the specific odor described, what is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Hydrogen sulphide poisoning

questions.text: A botanist studying psychoactive plants collects a sample with white, large, trumpet-shaped flowers. These distinctive features suggest the plant could be a source of which psychoactive compound?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyoscine

 

  • The correct answer is option B, Hyoscine, because the plant described with large, trumpet-shaped flowers matches the characteristic appearance of Datura, which contains hyoscine.
  • Hyoscine, also known as scopolamine, is an active compound found in Datura species, characterized by their large, trumpet-shaped flowers.
  • These plants are also known as thorn apple, Jimson weed, or Devil's trumpet.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Cocaine is derived from the leaves of the Erythroxylum coca plant, which has small flowers and red berries, not large trumpet-shaped flowers.

 

 

Option C) Nicotine is the active compound in tobacco plants, specifically Nicotiana tabacum, which has pinkish-white tubular flowers that differ in shape from the trumpet-like flowers of Datura.

 

 

Option D) Tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) is found in the Cannabis plant, which has small, tightly packed flowers that cluster at the top of the plant and are not large and trumpet-shaped.

questions.text:
During a rural health camp, a medical officer is educating the community about the risks associated with snakebites, particularly from venomous species. The officer emphasizes the importance of recognizing features of poisonous snakes for early identification and management. Which of the following characteristics is NOT typically associated with venomous snakes?

 

  1. They are primarily nocturnal in habit.
  2. They have a compressed tail.
  3. They possess solid and stout fangs.
  4. They exhibit large scales on their head.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3, 4

 

  • Poisonous snakes, particularly those belonging to the viper and elapid families, typically have hollow fangs that act as channels for injecting venom, contradicting statement 3, which suggests solid fangs.
  • Additionally, many venomous snakes have smaller, more numerous head scales rather than large ones, making statement 4 incorrect.

 

 

Other Options:

 

  1. Nocturnal in habit: This is a common characteristic of many poisonous snakes, allowing them to hunt and avoid predators under the cover of darkness.
  2. Have compressed tail: While some venomous snakes may exhibit a compressed tail, this feature is not a definitive indicator of venomous species and varies among different snake families.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Poisonous Vs non-poisonous snakes:

questions.text: In a case involving suspected arsenic poisoning, a forensic toxicologist is tasked with determining the distribution of arsenic within the body of the deceased. To ascertain the cause of death and gather evidence for potential legal proceedings, it is crucial to identify which organ would likely contain the greatest concentration of arsenic following exposure. Based on the typical accumulation pattern of heavy metals like arsenic in the human body, where would the greatest concentration of arsenic likely be found?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Liver

 

  • The liver is the organ where the greatest concentration of arsenic is likely to be found in the case of arsenic poisoning.
  • The liver is a key organ for detoxification and metabolism in the body, and it often bears the brunt of toxic substances, including heavy metals like arsenic.
  • Arsenic is metabolized in the liver, where it can bind to cellular components and disrupt metabolic processes.
  • This accumulation can lead to liver damage and failure, which are common outcomes of significant arsenic exposure.
  • Therefore, in forensic toxicology, the liver is a primary target for analysis in suspected cases of arsenic poisoning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Muscle: While arsenic can be distributed throughout the body's tissues, including muscle, it does not typically accumulate in muscle tissues to the same extent as it does in organs involved in filtration and metabolism, like the liver and kidneys.

 

Option B. Kidney: The kidneys also play a role in filtering blood and excreting waste products, including arsenic. Although arsenic can accumulate in the kidneys and cause damage, the liver generally shows higher concentrations due to its central role in metabolism and detoxification.

 

Option D. Brain: The brain is less likely to accumulate high concentrations of arsenic compared to the liver. While arsenic can cross the blood-brain barrier and potentially cause neurological effects, it is not the primary site of accumulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Arsenic accumulates predominantly in the liver due to its role in metabolism and detoxification. In cases of arsenic poisoning, the liver often shows the highest concentration of the toxin.

questions.text: A woman gives birth to two children at same time. One foetus is 32 weeks old on delivery and the second one is 36 weeks old. How is this Possible?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Superfetation

 

Superfetation refers to the phenomenon where a second ovum is fertilized and implants in the uterus at a different time during an already established pregnancy. This results in two fetuses of different gestational ages being carried at the same time. It is extremely rare but can happen when ovulation occurs again after a woman has already conceived, leading to the development of two fetuses with different ages, as described in this case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incorrect gestational age estimation: This option is incorrect because the scenario describes a significant difference in fetal age that would not typically be explained by a mere error in gestational age estimation.

 

Option B. Superfecundation: Superfecundation occurs when two ova are fertilized by sperm from separate acts of intercourse, but within the same ovulatory cycle. This would not explain the difference in gestational ages in this scenario.

 

Option D. Not Possible: This option is incorrect because superfetation, while rare, is a possible explanation for the different gestational ages of the fetuses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Superfetation is the occurrence of a second pregnancy during an existing one, leading to the development of two fetuses of different gestational ages.

questions.text: In a complex legal case involving the dispute of inheritance rights, a person is accused of presenting a living child, who is not their own, as if the child were born to them, in an attempt to manipulate the legal proceedings. This act is being scrutinized by forensic experts and legal professionals to understand its implications and relevance to the case. What term best describes this act, particularly in the context of claiming inheritance rights?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Suppositious Child

 

  • The term "Suppositious Child" specifically refers to the act of presenting a living child, who is not biologically one's own, as if born to oneself.
  • This act is often associated with motives such as claiming inheritance rights or manipulating familial relationships for personal gain.
  • The term encompasses the deliberate intent to deceive or commit fraud by introducing a child into a family lineage under false pretences.
  • This is a significant concept in forensic and legal contexts, especially in cases involving inheritance disputes, fraud, or the falsification of lineage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Posthumous child: This term refers to a child born after the death of a parent, typically the father. It does not relate to the act of presenting another's child as one's own.

 

Option B) Fictional child: While this term could conceptually align with fabricating the existence of a child, it does not specifically denote the legal or forensic act of presenting another's living child as one's own for inheritance or legal purposes.

 

Option D) Both B and C: Although "fictional child" could loosely relate to the concept of fabricating a child's existence or identity, "Suppositious Child" is the precise term used in legal and forensic contexts to describe the act in question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A "suppositious child" is fraudulently presented as one's own for financial gain, unlike a "posthumous child," born after the father's death, or a "fictional child," which is purely imaginary.

questions.text: In a forensic medicine lecture focusing on sexual disorders, the professor discusses various conditions that may have legal implications in cases involving allegations of impotence. A particularly interesting topic is a condition where a person is impotent towards one specific individual but not towards others. The professor presents this scenario to the medical students and asks them to identify the term that describes this selective type of impotence.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Impotence quoad hoc

 

Option D:

 

Impotence quoad hoc refers to a situation where a person is impotent towards one specific individual but is sexually functional with others. This condition is recognized in both medical and legal contexts, particularly in cases where impotence is claimed as a reason for annulment or divorce.

 

Until recently it was thought that psychological factors accounted for most cases of impotence. Nocturnal penile tumescence has revealed that a majority of cases of impotence have organic causes. Vasculogenic impotence is one of the most frequent causes of erectile failure (about 40%). Diabetes, hypertension, pelvic and genital injuries can cause reduction in blood flow (arteriogenic impotence), or excessive venous leakage of blood from the penis which can occur in adult life after years of normal sexual life or due to congenital anomalies (venogenic impotence) or both.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Frigidity: Typically used to describe a lack of sexual desire or response, especially in women.

 

Option B. Satyriasis: A condition of excessive sexual desire in men.

 

Option C. Sterile: Refers to the inability to reproduce, not to selective impotence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sterility refers to the inability of males to father children and females to conceive. Frigidity describes a woman's inability to initiate or maintain sexual arousal. Satyriasis is characterized by excessive sexual desire in males. Quoad hoc denotes a male's impotence with one specific woman, but not with others.

 

Ref: - Reddy 33/e. Pg 384

choices.text: Fecundum ab extra
Frigidity of constitution
Impotence quad hoc

questions.text: During a criminal investigation involving sexual offenses, a forensic medical examiner is asked to provide expert testimony. The case involves a male suspect who is accused of sexual misconduct, with a specific focus on his inability to deposit semen in the vaginal canal. The examiner is tasked with explaining the correct medical terminology for this condition. What is this condition known as?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fecundum ab extra

 

Option A:

 

Fecundum ab extra refers to the condition where a male fails to deposit semen within the vaginal canal. This term is significant in cases evaluating sexual performance or dysfunction in a forensic context.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Frigidity of constitution: Refers to a lack of sexual desire, It is the inability to initiate or maintain the sexual arousal pattern in female (absence of desire for sexual intercourse or incapacity to achieve orgasm)

 

Option C. Impotentia ejaculandi: Inability to ejaculate, but does not specifically refer to semen deposition within the vaginal canal.

 

Option D. Impotence quad hoc: Refers to impotence with a specific individual, A male may be impotent with one particular female, but not with another partner.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fecundation ab extra: Conception occurring in a woman when the semen was deposited on her thighs or on the vulva.

 

Ref: - Reddy 33/e. Pg 385

choices.text: Pharmacologically induced penile erection therapy

questions.text: A forensic expert is reviewing a medicolegal case involving a claim of impotence for marital dispute resolution. Part of the forensic evaluation involves differentiating between psychological and organic causes of erectile dysfunction. The expert plans to recommend a specific test to assist in this determination. Which test is most commonly used to differentiate between psychological and organic erectile dysfunction?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nocturnal penile tumescence

 

Option B:

 

Nocturnal penile tumescence (NPT) testing, also known as the "sleep erection test," is used to differentiate between psychological and organic causes of erectile dysfunction. NPT refers to the erections that occur during sleep. Normally, a man has 5–6 erections during sleep, especially during REM—their absence may indicate defect in nerve function or blood supply in the penis (Organic cause). Normal NPT is suggestive of a psychological cause of ED, as it indicates the physiological capability for erection.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pharmacologically induced penile erection therapy: Used to assess the ability to achieve an erection but does not specifically differentiate between psychological and organic causes.

 

Option C. Sildenafil induced erection: Useful in assessing response to medication, not in differentiating the cause of ED.

 

Option D. Squeeze technique: More related to premature ejaculation than to differentiating causes of ED.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective is to understand the use of nocturnal penile tumescence testing in the forensic evaluation of erectile dysfunction. This test is crucial for distinguishing between psychological and organic causes, aiding in medicolegal cases that involve claims related to sexual dysfunction, such as in marital disputes or compensation claims.

 

Ref: - Reddy 33/e. Pg 384

choices.text: Child who is born after the father dies
Child born through artificial insemination
Woman claims the child as her own
Child born out of wedlock

questions.text: In a medicolegal case involving disputed inheritance rights, a forensic expert is reviewing a situation where the legitimacy of a child's parentage is being questioned. The term "suppositious child" is used in the legal documents pertaining to the case. Understanding this term is crucial for the medical officer in providing an expert opinion. What is a "suppositious child"?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Woman claims the child as her own

 

Option C:

 

A "suppositious child" refers to a child whom a woman falsely claims as her own, often in legal disputes or cases of disputed parentage. It involves a false assertion of maternity. Mostly used for blackmailing (by claiming that she is pregnant by him to compel marriage. She may produce a suppositious child to extort money).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Child who is born after the father dies - This describes a posthumous child, not a suppositious child.

 

Option B. Child born through artificial insemination - This refers to a method of conception, not the legitimacy of the child's relationship to the parent.

 

Option D. Child born out of wedlock - This refers to the marital status of the parents at the time of the child's birth and does not inherently imply that the child is suppositious.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the legal concept of a suppositious child, which involves a false claim of maternity by a woman. This is done for obtaining money or for the purpose of claiming property or blackmailing a man or bringing a charge of breech of promise of marriage against a man. DNA fingerprinting will be conclusive.

 

Ref: - Reddy 33/e. Pg 397

choices.text: Incorrect gestational age estimation

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department in labor pains. The couple was previously counseled about their unique pregnancy after routine ultrasound findings. Upon examination, the casualty medical officer notes that the patient is indeed in labor and proceeds with the delivery. Surprisingly, she gives birth to twins at term. The first neonate appears slightly smaller and less developed compared to the second. Subsequent investigations reveal that the first neonate's gestational age is approximately 32 weeks, while the second neonate's gestational age is around 36 weeks. The medical officer is puzzled by this finding, considering the implications of such a rare event in their medical practice. How can the difference in gestational ages between the twins be best explained?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Superfetation

 

Option C:

 

In superfetation, the twins are conceived in different menstrual cycles, so either they are born at same time but with different development or born at different times with same development. Whereas, in superfecundation, both twins are conceived in same menstrual cycle, so have same development, and born at same time.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Incorrect gestational age estimation: It is highly unlikely as the maturity level of 32 weeks and 36 weeks baby will be very different.

 

Option B. Superfecundation: Fertilization of two ova discharged from the ovary at the same period of ovulation by two different acts of coitus committed at short intervals. The term is also used to refer to instances of two different males fathering fraternal twins. This leads to the possibility of twins also being half-siblings, classic example being one baby is white and the other black.

 

Option D. Not Possible: This scenario is possible as explained above

 

Educational Objective:

 

Similarities between Superfecundation and superfetation:

 

  • In both there is fertilization of 2 ova from 2 separate acts of coitus
  • So twin pregnany in both
  • Fathers can be different for the two babies in both superfecundation and superfetation.

 

Differences between Superfecundation and Superfetation:

 

  • In Superfecundation the two acts of coitus occurred in same menstrual cycle, whereas in superfetation in two different cycles.
  • Hence, in Superfecundation both fetuses have similar development, and born at same time.
  • Whereas, in superfetation, either they are born at same time but with different development or born at different times with same development.

 

Ref: - Reddy 33/e. Pg 396

choices.text: Fertilization of oocyte in the lab
Transfer of unfertilized egg into the fallopian tube

questions.text: In a forensic investigation related to a lawsuit involving a fertility clinic, a medical officer is reviewing the protocols for various assisted reproductive technologies. The medical officer needs to understand the specific steps involved in the Gamete Intrafallopian Transfer (GIFT) procedure to determine if the standard of care was met. Which of the following is NOT a step in the Gamete Intrafallopian Transfer (GIFT) procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fertilization of oocyte in the lab

 

Option C:

 

The key distinction of GIFT from other assisted reproductive technologies like in vitro fertilization (IVF) is that fertilization occurs inside the body, not in the lab. In GIFT, ovulation is stimulated, oocytes are retrieved, followed by laparoscopically guided transfer of a mixture of unfertilized eggs and sperms into the fallopian tube, where fertilization can naturally occur.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ovulation stimulation: This is a part of GIFT to produce multiple oocytes.

 

Option B. Oocyte retrieval: Necessary for collecting oocytes for the procedure.

 

Option D. Transfer of unfertilized egg into the fallopian tube: A critical step in GIFT where the eggs and sperm meet for natural fertilization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the steps involved in the Gamete Intrafallopian Transfer (GIFT) procedure. Unlike IVF, GIFT involves transferring unfertilized eggs and sperm into the fallopian tubes, where fertilization occurs naturally.

 

Ref: - Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3/e. Pg 351

questions.text: A forensic expert is providing expert testimony in a case involving the determination of a woman's stage of pregnancy. The focus is on identifying a specific pregnancy sign that can be observed after 16 weeks of gestation. What is the term for the intermittent, painless uterine contractions that can be appreciated per abdomen after this period?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Braxton-Hick's sign

 

Option D:

 

Braxton-Hick's sign refers to the intermittent, painless uterine contractions often felt after 16 weeks of gestation. These contractions are a normal part of pregnancy and differ from labor contractions.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Quickening: Refers to the first movements of the fetus felt by the mother.

 

Option B. Piskacek's sign: An early pregnancy sign indicating asymmetrical enlargement of the uterus.

 

Option C. Osiander's sign: An early pregnancy sign marked by increased pulsation in the lateral vaginal fornix.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Braxton-Hick's sign - Intermittent, painless uterine contractions are difficult to be observed before the third month but are easily felt after the fourth month. Each contraction lasts about a minute and relaxation for about two to three minutes. They are present even when the foetus is dead.

 

Ref: - Reddy 33/e. Pg 394

questions.text: In a medicolegal investigation regarding a case of alleged medical malpractice during early pregnancy, a medical officer is reviewing laboratory data to assess the progression of the pregnancy. Understanding the normal trends of hormonal changes during pregnancy is crucial in this context. At what gestational age do maternal human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) levels typically reach their maximum in a normal pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 8 to 10 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

In a normal pregnancy, the maternal hCG levels typically peak between 8 to 10 weeks of gestation. After this period, the levels generally stabilize or decrease slightly.

 

Some important pointers related to IMMUNOLOGICAL TESTS –

 

  • The hormone chorionic gonadotropin (HCG) and human chorionic somatomamnotropin (HCS) are secreted by the syncytial trophoblastic cells into the fluids of the mother.
  • It can be detected in maternal blood on about the 8th day after impregnation.
  • The rate of secretion rises rapidly to reach a maximum about seven weeks after conception, and decreases to a relatively low volume by 16 weeks after conception.
  • Because they are convenient and very reliable (accuracy 98% ), they have replaced bioassays for routine screening.
  • An early morning urine specimen will contain the highest level of HCG and is preferable for testing. Tests are positive 12 to 15 days after implantation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the typical timeline for peak hCG levels in early pregnancy (8-10 weeks), which is an important marker for confirming and monitoring the progression of pregnancy.

 

Ref: - Reddy 33/e. Pg 394

choices.text: Inheritance of features of the father
Inheritance of features of the mother
Inheritance of features of the grandfather
Inheritance of features of the uncle

questions.text: During a forensic seminar on genetic inheritance and its implications in criminal profiling, a medical officer is discussing the concept of atavism. Understanding this concept is crucial in the analysis of genetic traits that might be significant in certain forensic investigations. What is atavism in the context of genetic inheritance?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inheritance of features of the grandfather

 

Explanation:

 

Atavism refers to the inheritance of ancestral or primitive traits or characteristics that resemble those of a grandparent or earlier ancestor. It involves the reemergence of traits from a previous generation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the concept of atavism in genetic inheritance, which involves the reemergence of ancestral traits in descendants.

 

Ref: - Reddy 33/e. Pg 397

questions.text:
A 34-year-old woman presents to the postnatal ward of a district hospital after spontaneously delivering twins at full term. The delivery was uneventful, and both neonates are in good health. However, the attending medical officer notes that despite being twins, the neonates have markedly different physical features, as shown below. The mother, concerned about the differences between her children, consents to genetic testing to alleviate her fears. Surprisingly, the results reveal that only one of the twins is genetically related to the father.

 

 

What is the most likely explanation for the differing paternity results in these twins?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Superfecundation

 

Option B:

 

Fertilization of two ova discharged from the ovary at the same period of ovulation by two different acts of coitus committed at short intervals. The term is also used to refer to instances of two different males fathering fraternal twins, though this is more accurately known as heteropaternal superfecundation. This leads to the possibility of twins also being half-siblings, classic example being one baby is white and the other black.

 

Medico-legal aspect: Gross variations may occur in the complexion and features of the two babies and may give rise to the doubt of adultery and infidelity.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Not Possible - This option is incorrect because superfecundation, although rare, is a possible and documented phenomenon.

 

Option C. Superfetation - In superfetation, the twins are conceived in different menstrual cycles, so either they are born at same time but with different development, or born at different times with same development.

 

Option D. Suppositious child - Refers to a child who is falsely presented as another's own, which is not suggested by the information provided, as there is no indication that either child was intentionally substituted.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Similarities between Superfecundation and superfetation:

 

  • In both there is fertilization of 2 ova from 2 separate acts of coitus
  • So twin pregnany in both
  • Fathers can be different for the two babies in both Superfecundation and superfetation.

 

Differences between Superfecundation and superfetation:

 

  • In Superfecundation the two acts of coitus occurred in same menstrual cycle, whereas in superfetation in two different cycles.
  • Hence, in Superfecundation both fetuses have similar development, and are born at same time.
  • Whereas, in superfetation, the first fetus is more developed, and also, they may not be born at same time.

 

Ref: - Reddy 33/e. Pg 396

choices.text: The surrogate mother is not genetically related to the baby.
The surrogate mother carries an embryo created via in vitro fertilization.
The surrogate mother is also the egg donor and therefore the biological mother.
The surrogate mother carries the child for a family member.

questions.text: In a court case regarding surrogacy laws, a forensic expert is providing testimony on different types of surrogacy arrangements. The focus is on explaining the concept of 'traditional surrogacy' in the context of legal and ethical considerations. What does 'traditional surrogacy' refer to?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The surrogate mother is also the egg donor and therefore the biological mother

 

Option C:

 

In traditional surrogacy, the surrogate mother is also the egg donor, making her the biological mother of the child. This arrangement has significant legal and ethical implications in surrogacy cases.

 

Surrogacy - A surrogate mother is a woman who carries a child for a couple or a single person with intention of giving away the child to the parents, once it is born.

 

Types: 2 types –

 

  • Altruistic Surrogacy - No monetary compensation to the surrogate mother other than the medical expenses during pregnancy
  • Commercial surrogacy - For gaining monetary benefit or reward exceeding the basic medical expenses.

 

Commercial surrogacy is banned in India as per the recent surrogacy bill - 2016.

 

Salient features of the Indian Council of Medical Research Guidelines

 

  • Surrogate mother can be known, unknown or a relative of the couple. In the case of a relative, she should belong to the same generation as the woman desiring the surrogate.
  • Surrogacy should normally be considered only for parents for whom it would be physically or medically impossible or undesirable to carry a baby to term.
  • The genetic (biological) parents must adopt a child born through surrogacy.
  • The payment provided to the surrogate mother must include all expenses related to the pregnancy which must be documented through an agreement between the two.
  • The ART clinic cannot advertise to find a surrogate mother or be a party to any commercial dealing in gestational surrogacy. The responsibility of finding a surrogate mother rests completely with the couple.
  • The surrogate mother should be < 45 years of age and passes all treatable criteria to ensure full-term pregnancy.
  • No individual can be a surrogate mother more than thrice in a lifetime.
  • The ART clinic is responsible for guiding the couples through the processes of egg and embryo donation, and surrogacy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The surrogate mother is not genetically related to the baby: This describes gestational surrogacy.

 

Option B. The surrogate mother carries an embryo created via in vitro fertilization: This could describe gestational surrogacy.

 

Option D. The surrogate mother carries the child for a family member: This is a specific scenario that can occur in either traditional or gestational surrogacy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The surrogate mother may be the baby’s biological mother (traditional surrogacy) or she may be implanted with someone else’s fertilized egg (gestational surrogacy). She accepts pregnancy either by AI or by implantation of in vitro fertilized ova at the blastocyst stage, till delivery, for the woman who is incapable to bear child.

 

Ref: - Reddy 33/e. Pg 388

questions.text: In a medical-legal consultation, a medical officer is reviewing a case involving a female patient who is unable to engage in sexual intercourse, a condition that is affecting her marital life. This condition is a crucial aspect of the ongoing legal dispute concerning the marriage. The medical officer needs to identify the most likely condition associated with this type of sexual dysfunction in females. Which condition is most likely associated with impotence in females, defined as the inability to engage in sexual intercourse?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vaginismus

 

Option C:

 

Vaginismus is a condition where there is involuntary spasmodic contraction of the muscles around the vagina due to hyperaesthesia, making sexual intercourse painful or impossible. This condition can lead to female impotence, as it prevents successful vaginal penetration. It is a classical example of a psychosomatic illness.

 

Severe spasm of the lower one-third of vagina involving the paravaginal muscles (levator ani and adductor femoris muscle)]. The spastic contraction of vaginal outlet is an involuntary reflex which replaces the rhythmic contraction associated with anticipated or actual attempt of vaginal penetration.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Gonadal dysgenesis: Affects the development of the gonads but does not directly cause impotence.

 

Option B. Hermaphrodite: Refers to having both male and female reproductive organs, not directly related to the inability to engage in sexual intercourse.

 

Option D. Absence of ovary: While it affects fertility, it does not necessarily result in impotence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the concept of female impotence, particularly in the context of legal disputes involving marital issues or sexual health, focusing on vaginismus, a condition that results in the involuntary contraction of vaginal muscles, thereby hindering sexual intercourse, lead to female impotence.

 

Ref: - Reddy 33/e. Pg 385

questions.text: In a forensic investigation related to a potential case of statutory rape, a medical officer is examining evidence to ascertain the timeline of a teenager's pregnancy. The investigation requires determining the earliest point at which the pregnancy could have been detected. The medical records indicate that a Gravindex test was conducted. For accurate forensic documentation, it is crucial to know how early this test can detect pregnancy. How early can the Gravindex test detect pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

The Gravindex test (Indirect agglutination inhibition test), a urine pregnancy test, can detect pregnancy as early as 2 weeks after conception. This corresponds to around the time of the missed menstrual period, as it detects the presence of hCG, even two days after the missed period.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the capability of the Gravindex test in early pregnancy detection, which is able to identify pregnancy about 2 weeks after conception by detecting hCG in urine.

 

Ref: - Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3/e. Pg 357

questions.text: In a forensic case involving an allegation of infant abandonment soon after birth, a medical officer is evaluating the mother's medical condition to determine the postpartum period. Understanding the normal postpartum changes, including the phases of lochia discharge, is crucial for timing the events accurately. What is the correct order of the phases of lochia discharge following childbirth?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rubra, serosa, alba

 

Explanation:

 

The correct order of the phases of lochia discharge following childbirth is rubra, serosa, and alba. 

 

It is a discharge from the uterus which lasts for two or three weeks. It has a peculiar sour, -. During the first 4 to 5 days, the discharge is bright-red and contains large clots (lochia rubra). During the next four days, it becomes serous and paler in colour (lochia serosa). After the ninth day colour becomes yellowish-grey or turbid (lochia alba) until its final disappearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the sequence of lochia discharge phases, which is an important aspect of postpartum care. Lochia rubra is the initial red discharge, followed by lochia serosa (pinkish-brown), and finally, lochia alba (yellowish-white).

 

Ref: - Reddy 33/e. Pg 398

choices.text: Both B and C

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to a community health center with a newborn, claiming to have delivered the child at home with the help of a local midwife. She requests a birth certificate and insists on documenting the child as the heir to her recently divorced husband, alleging the conception occurred prior to their separation. What term best describes the act of presenting a living child, not one's own, as if born to oneself, particularly to claim inheritance rights?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Suppositious Child

 

Option C:

 

The fraud child presented for the purpose of financial gain is typically called suppositious child. These arose when an heir was required and so a suitable baby might be procured and passed off as genuine. It is a fraudulent offspring.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Posthumous Child: It is a child born after the death of its father; the mother being conceived by the said father.

 

Option B. Fictional Child: A "fictitious child" generally refers to a child who does not exist and is purely a creation of imagination or fiction. Fictitious children are often found in literature, storytelling etc. So, while a suppositious child is a fraud, but do exist in reality, whereas fictional children do not exist at all.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A "suppositious child" is fraudulently presented as one's own for financial gain, unlike a "posthumous child," born after the father's death, or a "fictional child," which is purely imaginary.

 

Ref: - Reddy 33/e. Pg 397

questions.text: A forensic expert is conducting a workshop on various tests used to determine live birth in cases of infant death. These tests are essential to distinguish between infants who were born alive and those who were stillborn. Which of the following tests is not used to detect live birth?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Winslow test

 

Option D:

 

Winslow’s test: No movement of reflection of light shown on mirror or surface of water in bowl kept on the chest. Now obsolete. The Winslow test is not specifically used to detect live birth.

 

Other Tests to detect stoppage of respiration (obsolete)

 

  • Feather test: No movement is seen, if a feather or fine cotton fibers are held before the nostrils.
  • Mirror test: No haziness is seen on the reflecting surface of the mirror held in front of mouth and nostrils.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fodere's test is used to demonstrate lung floatation, indicative of breathing and thus live birth. The lungs are ligated across their hila and separated. The average weight of both lungs before respiration varies from 30 to 40 g., and after respiration from 60 to 66 g. The increase in weight is due to the increased flow of blood.

 

Option B. Ploucquet's test is another lung floatation test used to determine if an infant had breathed. The ratio of the weight of the lungs and the whole body is reduced to half (1/35 of body weight) as compared to the said ratio before respiration (1/70 of body weight).

 

Option C. Wredin's test - Before birth, the middle ear contains gelatinous embryonic connective tissue but no air. With respiration, the sphincter at the pharyngeal end of eustachian tube relaxes and air replaces the gelatinous substances in few hours to five weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding different forensic tests used to detect live birth and distinguishing them from tests that serve other purposes.

 

  • Winslow test = test to determine stoppage of respiration
  • Fodere's test = weight of lungs before respiration -30 to 40 g after respiration-60 to 66 g
  • Plocquet's test = ratio of weight of lungs to weight of body; before respiration = 1:70 and after respiration = 1:35
  • Wredin's test = before respiration gelatinous tissue in middle ear & after respiration, air in middle ear

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 152, 439

choices.text: Injuries sustained are non-accidental
Undue delay in seeking medical advice
The history is consistent with the injuries
Injuries are of different duration

questions.text: In a lecture on child abuse, the professor discusses Caffey's Syndrome, a condition often associated with non-accidental injuries in children. The students are asked to identify which feature is not true regarding Caffey's Syndrome. Which of the following statements about Caffey's Syndrome is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The history is consistent with the injuries.

 

Option C:

 

In cases of Caffey's Syndrome, which is often associated with child abuse, the history provided by caregivers often does not correlate with the injuries observed, making option C incorrect.

 

Battered Baby Syndrome: It is also known as child abuse syndrome, Caffey’s syndrome or non-accidental injury of childhood. The classical features are:

 

  1. Discrepancy between the nature of injuries and the explanation offered by the parents.
  2. Delay between injury and medical attention cannot be explained by caregiver.
  3. Injuries of different age groups
  4. Victims are usually male of less than 3 years old and belong to low social class and education.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Injuries sustained are non-accidental: True, as Caffey's Syndrome is often linked to child abuse.

 

Option B. Undue delay in seeking medical advice: True, and this delay in seeking treatment is a common feature in child abuse cases.

 

Option D. Injuries are of different duration: True, indicating repeated abuse over time, with injuries in various stages of healing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A battered child is one who has received repetitive physical injuries as a result of nonaccidental violence, produced by a parent or guardian. In addition to physical injury, there may be non-accidental deprivation of nutrition, care and affection. The key identifier is the inconsistency between the history provided and the injuries observed, which is a hallmark of non-accidental injury in child abuse cases.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 445

choices.text: Abnormality of the uterus

questions.text: During a medical conference, a discussion arises about the different causes of spontaneous abortion in the second trimester. What is the most common cause of spontaneous abortion in the second trimester?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cervical incompetence

 

Option B:

 

Cervical incompetence, characterized by the inability of the cervix to retain a pregnancy, is the most common cause of spontaneous abortions in the second trimester. This condition leads to premature dilation and effacement of the cervix, often resulting in mid-pregnancy loss.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Chromosomal defect: More common in the first trimester.

 

Option C. Abnormality of the uterus: Less common than cervical incompetence for second-trimester losses.

 

Option D. Infections: While a potential cause, they are not as common as cervical incompetence in the second trimester.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cervical incompetence is the primary cause of second-trimester abortion, underscoring the significance of cervical integrity in maintaining pregnancy.

Cervico-uterine (Anatomic) factors usually cause second trimester abortions.

 

  • Cervical incompetence.
  • Congenital malformation of uterus, e.g. hypoplasia, bicornuate/septate uterus or duplication of upper part of uterus.
  • Uterine fibroid

 

Ref:  Reddy 33/e. Pg 400

questions.text: A medical officer is conducting a postmortem examination in a district hospital on a 45-year-old male who was found dead in his home office. The deceased had a history of depression but no known physical health issues. The postmortem reveals no signs of physical trauma, but a white crystalline substance is found in the stomach contents.
