Toxicological analysis identifies the substance as borax. In this suspected suicide case, which pharmacological effect of borax is most pertinent?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Emmenagogues

 

Option D:

 

Borax is classified as an emmenagogue (Abortifacient drugs). Emmenagogues are substances that stimulate or increase menstrual flow. Borax has been historically used for its emmenagogic properties, although it is not commonly used in modern medical practice due to safety concerns.

 

Emmenagogues drugs - estrogen, savin, borax or sanguinarine

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Gastrointestinal irritants: These causes irritation of uterus, e.g. purgatives, like castor or croton oil, julap, senna or MgSO4.

 

Option B. Genitourinary irritants: They produce reflex uterine contraction, e.g. cantharides, oil of turpentine or tansy or pennyroyal.

 

Option C. Ecbolics: Refers to substances that stimulate uterine contractions. Ex - Ergot preparations, synthetic estrogens, pituitary extract, strychnine or quinine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Abortifacient drugs: Most of them have no effect on the uterus or fetus, unless given in toxic doses, and often sold to exploit distressed woman. Usually used in the 2nd month of pregnancy.

 

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 402

choices.text: Amniotic fluid embolism

questions.text: In a pathology laboratory, a medical officer is analyzing tissue samples from a deceased pregnant woman who suddenly collapsed and died. The medical history and symptoms prior to death suggest a rare but serious complication. The medical officer decides to use Lendrum's stain in the histopathological examination of the lung tissue. For which type of embolism is Lendrum's stain specifically used?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Amniotic fluid embolism

 

Option C:

 

Lendrum’s stain (Phloxine-Tartrazine): This stain is useful to detect amniotic fluid embolism deaths, since keratin of amniotic squames is stained red, nuclei blue and cytoplasm yellow.

 

The ‘WHO’ method: It is helpful to demonstrate keratin and mucin-like substances in amniotic fluid embolism.

 

Some important Pointers related to Amniotic Fluid Embolism

 

  • Most of the cases occur during: 1st and 2nd trimester abortion;  Active labor; Amniocentesis; Abdominal trauma
  • Amniotic fluid embolism is a rare, unforeseeable and dreadful complication. This occurs when massive amount of amniotic fluid enters the maternal venous system.
  • There may be tonic-clonic seizures, breathlessness and loss of consciousness. In half the cases, death occurs in the first hour.
  • It causes DIC and fibrin deposition in many organs.
  • Diagnosis is established by demonstration of mucin, lanugo hair, vernix caseosa, fat globules, meconium and fetal squamous cells in cut sections of the lung.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Air embolism: Not identifiable with Lendrum's stain.

 

Option B. Fat embolism: Detected through different staining techniques.

 

Option D. Pulmonary embolism: The nature of the embolus (e.g., thrombus, fat, air) dictates the staining technique, not the location.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lendrum's stain is used in forensic pathology for the identification of amniotic fluid embolism, a critical diagnostic tool in cases of maternal death where this condition is suspected.

 

Cause of Death in Criminal Abortion

 

  • Immediate: Air embolism, fat embolism, amniotic fluid embolism, hemorrhage, vagal inhibition.
  • Delayed (with 2 to 3 days): Septicemia, generalized peritonitis, tetanus, local infection & toxemia.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 410

questions.text: A medical officer is conducting a forensic examination in a case involving a late-term abortion. To assist in determining the gestational age of the fetus at the time of the abortion, the medical officer is reviewing the mother's medical records for documented physical examination findings. External ballottement is a technique used to assess fetal development. After how many weeks of gestation can external ballottement typically be performed in a normal pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 20 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

External ballottement, a technique where the fetus can be felt to rebound against the examiner's fingers during a pelvic examination, is typically possible after about 20 weeks of gestation. This is when the fetus is large enough to be palpated through the abdominal wall.

 

Demonstration

 

  • Vaginal/internal ballottement: Two fingers are inserted into the anterior fornix and a sudden upward motion given. This causes the fetus to move up in the liquor amnii and after a moment, the fetus drops down on the fingers, like a ball bouncing back.
  • External ballottement: A sudden motion is given to the abdominal wall covering the uterus, in a few seconds the rebound of the fetus can be felt.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ballottement (toss up like a ball): This is positive during the 4th–5th month of pregnancy as the fetus is small in relation to the amount of amniotic fluid present. This is a useful clinical sign for assessing fetal development around the midpoint of the gestation period.

 

Ref:  Reddy 33/e. Pg 394

questions.text: In a case under investigation at a district hospital, a medical officer is required to estimate the gestational age of a fetus as part of a forensic examination. This is crucial in a legal case involving questions around the time of conception and fetal viability. The medical officer refers to ultrasound findings for accurate dating of the pregnancy. At the earliest, by which week of gestation can the gestational sac be seen using ultrasonography?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 5th week

 

Option C:

 

During a forensic autopsy, the gestational sac can typically be visualized using ultrasonography at the earliest by the 5th week of gestation. This information is crucial in determining the age of the fetus for forensic purposes.

 

Transvaginal sonography (TVS) can detect cardiac activity by 5th week and transabdominal sonography by 6th week. A real-time scanner can detect cardiac activity by 8th week. Doppler ultrasound can pick up the fetal heart rate reliably by 10th week (average 8–10 weeks).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. 3rd week - Not visible

 

Option B. 4th week: Gestational sac is visible after 4 completed week

 

Option D. 8th week: By this time, more advanced fetal structures, beyond just the gestational sac, are visible in forensic ultrasonography, like - Eyes and nose recognizable, hands and feet are webbed. Anus is seen as dark spot. Placenta is formed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The gestational sac, the earliest sonographic evidence of pregnancy, can typically be visualized by the 5th week of gestation. This is an important milestone in early pregnancy and is crucial for confirming intrauterine pregnancy.

 

Ref:  Reddy 33/e. Pg 396

choices.text: Direct Coomb’s test

questions.text: During a postmortem examination of a pregnant woman at a district hospital, a medical officer is investigating a case involving suspected complications related to fetomaternal hemorrhage. To determine if there was a transfusion of fetal red blood cells (RBCs) into the mother's circulation, a specific diagnostic test is required. Which test is used to detect fetomaternal transfusion of fetal RBCs in the mother's circulation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Betke-Kleihauer test

 

Option B:

 

In a postmortem examination of a pregnant woman, the Betke-Kleihauer test is used to detect fetomaternal transfusion of fetal red blood cells (RBCs) in the mother's circulation. This information can be crucial in understanding the circumstances surrounding the individual's death, especially in cases involving maternal-fetal health issues.

 

Betke-Kleihauer test: This is a staining technique in which fetal cells can be distinguished from adult red cells. A blood smear is prepared from the mother’s blood and exposed to an acid bath. This removes adult hemoglobin, but not fetal hemoglobin from the red blood cells. Subsequent staining makes fetal cells (containing fetal hemoglobin) appear rose-pink in color, while adult red blood cells are only seen as ‘ghosts.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Direct Coomb’s test: Detects antibodies on the surface of red blood cells, not specifically for fetomaternal transfusion.

 

Option C. Electrophoresis: Used for analyzing the mobility of charged particles, not specific to this scenario.

 

Option D. Indirect Coomb’s test: Detects antibodies in the mother's serum, often used in blood typing and antibody screening, but not specific to fetomaternal transfusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Betke-Kleihauer test during postmortem examinations of pregnant women, helps in detecting fetomaternal transfusion of fetal red blood cells in the mother's circulation. This knowledge is crucial in forensic postmortem examinations of pregnant women, particularly in cases where fetomaternal hemorrhage is suspected, to establish the cause and circumstances of complications or death.

 

Ref: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3/e. Pg 358

questions.text: In a rural district hospital, a medical officer was called to investigate a distressing case involving a newborn found abandoned near a local pond. The circumstances surrounding the newborn's discovery raised concerns about possible infanticide. To assist in the investigation, the medical officer decided to perform a series of tests as part of the autopsy to determine whether the newborn had been born alive and breathed before death. In which test weight of lungs is compared with body weight?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ploucquet's Test

 

 

Option B:

 

Ploucquet's Test is the test in which weight of lungs is compared with body weight. This test helps to demonstrate establishment of respiration. The ratio of the weight of the lungs and the whole body is reduced to half (1/35 of body weight) as compared to before respiration (1/70 of body weight).

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Static test or Fodere's test: The test based on lung weight useful in the diagnosis of live birth is static test. The average weight of both lungs before respiration is 35 gm and after respiration is 70 gm. There is no comparison with the body weight.

 

Option C. Raygatâs test (Hydrostatic test, Breslauâs 1st life test): Raygatâs test is based on specific gravity of lung. The specific gravity of a non-respired lung is 1040-1050 and of a respired lung is 940-950, so, after respiration lung floats on water (specific gravity of water is 1000). There is no comparison of lung weight to body weight.

 

Option D. Wredin's test: This test is based on the fact that before birth middle ear contains gelatinous embryonic tissue, which is replaced by air after respiration. So, the presence of air in middle ears denotes live birth. There is no role of weight of lungs.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 439
